Posts.Title: Choosing not to have axillary node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi I'm in a similar position in terms of diagnosis. Following bilateral surgery and sentinel node biopsy it was found I had one positive node "with macrometastases and extra capsular involvement". Only 3 nodes were removed. I'm on the POSNOC trial and have been randomised to no treatment so there will be no further intervention to my lymph nodes. If I'd been randomised to the other arm of the study my options would be axillary node clearance or radiotherapy to the armpit.  I'm a bit confused about the extra capsular bit - it wasn't mentioned in my results appointment at all and I only spotted it in a letter to my GP which I'd been copied in on. I'm having chemo at the moment and hoping this will sort my lymph nodes out too.  I'm wondering if I should withdraw from trial and opt for radiotherapy but I'm not sure it's an option.  Good luck with your decision- I feel I'm making decisions that have horribly real implications for my future without all the facts. Hugs  Helen xx
Posts.Title: Choosing not to have axillary node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Suzi POSNOC is positive sentinel node adjuvant therapy alone versus adjuvant therapy plus clearance or axillary radiotherapy (catchy title!)  My understanding is that they feel they are overtreating younger women with only one node involved and consequently causing unnecessary lymphoedema etc.  I'm being treated at Royal united hospital in Bath but it's a national multi centre trial so should be available all over the country.  You are correct- you and your treatment team have no choice over which arm you are randomised too it's all done my computer.  Hope that helps Helen xx
